greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = largest divisor of n which is coprime to the largest proper divisor of n. (a(1)=1.).
comment: Also the denominator of the ratio of the largest proper divisor to the least prime divisor of n, which can be thought of as the ratio of the 2nd largest divisor to the 2nd least divisor of n. - _Michel Marcus_, Feb 27 2017
link: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: For n >= 2: Let p =A020639(n) be the smallest prime dividing n. If p^2 divides n, then a(n)=1. Otherwise, a(n) = p.
example: The largest proper divisor of 30 is A032742(30) = 15. So a(30)= 2, because 2 is the largest divisor of 30 which is coprime to 15.
mathematica: f[n_] := Block[{d = Divisors[n]},If[n < 2, 1, Max @@ Select[d, GCD[ #, d[[ -2]]] == 1 &]]];Array[f, 100] (* _Ray Chandler_, Feb 26 2007 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = if (n==1, 1, my(d = divisors(n)); k = #d; while (gcd(d[k], d[#d-1]) != 1, k--); d[k]); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Feb 27 2017
(PARI) a(n) = if (n==1, 1, my(d = divisors(n)); denominator(d[#d-1]/d[2])); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Feb 27 2017
(PARI) a(n)=if(n==1, return(1)); my(f=factor(n)[1,]); if(f[2]>1, 1, f[1]) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Feb 27 2017
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, Feb 17 2007
